repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
- ref #30415
- add help tags for common searches on https://neovim.io/
- fix #31327

comment_data.body:
> Whereas we can always compose any two applicatives to form a composite applicative, two monads do not in general compose to form a monad. 

> If we know that an applicative functor is a monad, we gain some expressive power that we donâ€™t get with just an applicative functor.

> When we move fom Euclidean to Cartesian geometry, we lose the ability to assume isotropy of space, intersection of curves, and compatibility between dimensions.

Are you using `develop.txt` as your personal bookmark or something? Wtf is this?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -300,10 +300,15 @@ vim.paste in runtime/lua/vim/_editor.lua like this: >
     --- @returns false if client should cancel the paste.
 
 
-LUA STDLIB DESIGN GUIDELINES                            *dev-lua*
+STDLIB DESIGN GUIDELINES                                             *dev-lua*
 
 See also |dev-naming|.
 
+- "A restriction at one semantic level translates to freedom and power at
+  another semantic level." https://blog.higher-order.com/blog/2014/12/21/maximally-powerful/

comment_data.body: Certainly not mathematics, I can tell you that...

comment_data.body:
> Are you using `develop.txt` as your personal bookmark or something? Wtf is this?

You quoted stuff I didn't put here. But yes, I put things in branches that may not make it into master.

This was some fumbling around trying to get some intuition of the "expression problem". Which seems to be the name for our constant struggles with API design.

> Who is the target audience here?

Nvim developers
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -300,10 +300,15 @@ vim.paste in runtime/lua/vim/_editor.lua like this: >
     --- @returns false if client should cancel the paste.
 
 
-LUA STDLIB DESIGN GUIDELINES                            *dev-lua*
+STDLIB DESIGN GUIDELINES                                             *dev-lua*
 
 See also |dev-naming|.
 
+- "A restriction at one semantic level translates to freedom and power at
+  another semantic level." https://blog.higher-order.com/blog/2014/12/21/maximally-powerful/

comment_data.body: And this "personal bookmark" is something I put here in earnest to try to help others. So fuck off. ðŸ–•

comment_data.body:
> You quoted stuff I didn't put here.

I quoted stuff in the linked article, which I assumed one would need to read in order to understand the context of the quote.

> But yes, I put things in branches that may not make it into master.

How should I know which changes are "not for master" and which changes that are for master? I can only review the changes I see.

> This was some fumbling around trying to get some intuition of the "expression problem". Which seems to be the name for our constant struggles with API design.

Sure, but this seems to almost make things more confusing? I'm not sure what conclusions or guidance one should get from it. It kinda gives off the vibes that the design of neovim is left as an exercise to the reader.

> And this "personal bookmark" is something I put here in earnest to try to help others. So fuck off. ðŸ–•

OK, didn't expect that reaction. I could've worded my confusion better, I apologize for how I phrased it.

I don't doubt you found it helpful. I found it unhelpful, pretentious, lacking in substance and ultimately that my time was wasted and am also earnestly trying to help people avoid the same experience. I have said my peace, I will now fuck off ðŸ«¡

comment_data.body: `and (filter._uninitialized or client.initialized)` ensures only initialized clients get returned.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -777,6 +777,8 @@ end
 
 --- Get active clients.
 ---
+--- The returned client(s) may not yet be fully initialized.
